lead: This week in tech: Apple is reportedly developing a new AI wearable, while AI's impact on business profitability is under scrutiny. Meanwhile, the debate over AI chip exports continues to heat up.

stories.title: Apple is reportedly working on an AirTag-sized AI wearable
stories.summary: Apple is developing a new AI-powered wearable device that resembles an AirTag, featuring multiple cameras and microphones to capture the user's environment. The device is still in early development and could launch as soon as 2027. This move aligns with Apple's strategy to enhance its AI capabilities, particularly in light of recent collaborations with Google.

stories.title: AI hasn't delivered the profits it was hyped for, says Deloitte
stories.summary: A new report from Deloitte indicates that businesses are struggling to realize the profitability gains that AI was expected to deliver. Many companies are still in the early stages of AI adoption, leading to a gap between expectations and actual financial benefits. This raises questions about the sustainability of AI investments in the current economic climate.

stories.title: Washington Is Divided on AI Chip Exports as Anthropic CEO Deems China Sales a ‘Mistake’
stories.summary: The debate over AI chip exports to China is intensifying, with Congress considering more authority over such transactions. Anthropic's CEO has publicly criticized these sales as a mistake, reflecting broader concerns about national security and technological competition. The situation highlights the complexities of regulating advanced technology in a global market.

stories.title: Siri Reinvented as a ChatGPT Rival? The Rumors Are Getting a Lot Louder
stories.summary: Apple's Siri is reportedly undergoing a significant transformation to become a more interactive AI chatbot, similar to ChatGPT. This upgrade is expected to roll out later this year, potentially changing how users interact with their Apple devices. The move indicates Apple's commitment to staying competitive in the rapidly evolving AI landscape.

stories.title: Marshall's new Heddon hub adds multi-room audio to speakers with Auracast
stories.summary: Marshall has introduced the Heddon hub, a new device that enables multi-room audio for its Bluetooth speakers using Auracast technology. Priced at $300, the hub allows users to synchronize older Marshall speakers with modern streaming services. This innovation aims to extend the life of existing audio systems and enhance the listening experience.

stories.title: Eightfold sued for helping companies secretly score job seekers
stories.summary: Eightfold, an AI recruitment platform, is facing legal action for allegedly enabling companies to covertly score job applicants. The lawsuit raises significant ethical concerns regarding transparency and fairness in AI-driven hiring practices. This case could set a precedent for how AI technologies are regulated in recruitment.

stories.title: Bezos' Blue Origin to deploy enterprise-grade LEOsat network
stories.summary: Blue Origin, founded by Jeff Bezos, is set to launch an enterprise-grade Low Earth Orbit satellite network capable of delivering speeds up to 6Tbps. This initiative aims to enhance global connectivity, particularly for businesses in remote areas. The project underscores the growing competition in the satellite internet sector.

stories.title: AI-Powered Impersonation Is Emerging as a Top Cyberthreat for 2026
stories.summary: As AI technology advances, the threat of AI-powered impersonation is becoming a significant concern for cybersecurity in 2026. A recent survey shows that 68% of consumers are worried about identity theft, highlighting the urgent need for enhanced security measures. This trend poses challenges for both individuals and organizations in protecting sensitive information.

stories.title: Kioxia's memory is 'sold out' for 2026, prolonging a 'high-end and expensive phase'
stories.summary: Kioxia has announced that its memory products are sold out for 2026, indicating a prolonged phase of high prices and limited availability. The company is ramping up manufacturing capacity, but relief for consumers and manufacturers alike may come slowly. This situation reflects ongoing supply chain challenges in the semiconductor industry.

stories.title: ‘Pirates of the Caribbean’ Director Has a Theory on Why Visual FX Suck So Much Now
stories.summary: Director Gore Verbinski has shared his insights on the decline in quality of visual effects in modern films. He suggests that the software used in the industry may be to blame, raising questions about the tools and techniques employed in contemporary filmmaking. This commentary adds to the ongoing discourse about the future of visual storytelling.
